title: Correct represented -> representation
body: I assume this was the original intention, otherwise I'm not sure what this passage is trying to say!

title: Instant Unions
body:
[#115] Introduces explanations- proofs of equality between two terms in the egraph. To support the PR, egg was modified so that all unions were delayed until rebuild is called. This made explanations easier to implement because there is an up-to-date hashcons (memo for enodes in the egraph).

However, it turns out that carefully re-writing how enodes are added to the egraph avoids this issue. This PR restores egg's functionality to perform unions immediately. It also restores the rebuild algorithm to what it was before proofs were added. The core idea of the PR is to make sure that proofs have access to the correct uncanonicalized enode.

title: Replace Mutex with RwLock in string interning code.
body: When calling into egg from multiple threads, the `Mutex` used for `STRINGS` can become a bottleneck. (In my use case, I have a few hundred expressions that I'd like egg to simplify, so I do that using multiple threads.) In that context, I observed that `egg::util::intern` was a significant fraction of total runtime and that more time was spent in it than in any of the rest of egg's code(!). Here is what `perf` on Linux reported: (Note that is in the context of a larger application; just over half of total runtime is in egg but that 43% is with respect to total runtime.) Total runtime for my test is 4.04s user, 14.22s sys. This PR replaces the `Mutex` is replaced with a reader-writer lock. `perf` reports roughly a 2x speedup: which is also reflected in the total runtime for my system going to 9.26s user, 0.21s sys.

title: Fix Explanation Initialization to Share Subexpressions
body:
This PR fixes https://github.com/egraphs-good/egg/issues/153, which points out that for large recexprs explanations are large and slow.
Previously, the explanations code failed to share subexpressions as `RecExpr` does when initializing the proof.

title: Fix broken link in Cargo.toml
body:
Hi,

I noticed that the repository link for egg on [crates.io](https://crates.io/crates/egg) leads to `https://github.com/egraph-good/egg` which does not seem to exist. The small change in this PR changes the URL in the cargo manifest to `https://github.com/egraphs-good/egg`. I assume that this will fix the link on crates.io when the next version of egg is released.

Feel free to close this PR and fix the link yourself, if there is some problem

title: removed unnecessary mut on extractor in getting started example
Add LP extractor
body: This adds an Extractor that can do common subexpression elimination using linear programming. WIP

title: Fix up documentation example of apply_one, which now needs to perform unions
Existance Explanations
body:
Sometimes, it's unclear why an expression is represented in the egraph in the first place. In fact, these "magic terms" can sometimes be critical in finding an equality. Consider:
```
0
(Rewrite<= times-zero (* (/ 1 0) 0))
(Rewrite=> cancel-denominator 1)
```

`(* (/ 1 0) 0))` is a magic term, and we would like a proof of how it got to be in the egraph in the first place. I call these existence explanations, and this PR implements them. Whenever a term is added to the egraph, the `Explain` keeps track of where it came from. This could be either from a rule application, from a parent being inserted, or from congruence. Existance explanations simply follow the chain of pointers back to an original term manually added to the egraph.

title: Egg Proof Production
body:
This PR adds the ability to generate explanations for two terms being equivalent in the graph to egg. The `explain_equivalence` function on the runner provides an `Explanation` for two `RecExpr` being equal. This explanation has a tree format as well as a flattened format. In the tree format, children can be proofs. In the flattened format, there is only one rewrite happening between terms.

Users who which to perform unions themselves (either in custom appliers or in analyses) are required to use the `union_with_justification` function, which requires two patterns (lhs and rhs) and their substitution justifying the union. The `Explain` data structure internally finds enodes corresponding to the e-match for those patterns. 

Implementing proof-production involved some interesting design decisions. The biggest question is how to efficiently find the enodes corresponding to the user-given pattern. When the egraph congruence invariant is maintained, this is easy because the hash-cons allows us to find each node matching the pattern from bottom-up. So the solution in this PR is that whenever `union_with_justification` is called, the congruence invariant needs to be true.

Here's how that works:
- Instead of applying each union directly, unions are put on a `to_union` stack and delayed until rebuilding. So until rebuilding, the memo remains updated and calls to `union_with_justification` are valid.
- At rebuilding, we apply all the unions.
- Previously, maintenance of analysis was interweaved with rebuilding, but this won't work anymore because congruence has not been restored.
- So after rebuilding, we apply analysis results and rebuild again until fixpoint. But further analysis unions must also be delayed, so there is another stack for that. So far it's unclear what the performance hit of doing this is.


This PR isn't ready yet- I've posted it so @mwillsey and others can see it.
TODOS:
- [x] Documentation of functions
- [x] Documentation of proof generation, including explanations of explanation trees and flattened explanations
- [x] Make proof-generation flag work, including disallowing calling `union` directly in explanation-generation mode
- [x] Caching in proof-generation
- [x] Decided against adding Herbie benchmarks
- [x] Let bindings so you can reuse proofs in the printed output
- [x] Benchmarking how the change to rebuilding affects performance
- [x] Reduce overhead of proof production when feature is off- don't delay unions?
- [x] Change rewrite rule string to an Arc
- [x] Simplify union_with_justification api
- [x] Pass patternast as a Cow from apply_one
- [x] Optional- add tutorial

title: Move printing to `Display` and parsing to a new trait, `FromOp`.
body:
This fixes #83 by replacing `Language::display_op` with ~`OpStr::fmt`~ `Display`. It also moves `Language::from_op_str` to ~`OpStr::from_str`~ `FromOp::from_op`. Moving these two functions to a separate trait eliminates the need to give them default implementations which panic. `define_language!` has been updated to automatically implement ~`OpStr`~ `Display` and `FromOp`, so the transition should be seamless for people using the macro.

Additionally, this pull request adds a dependency on [thiserror](https://docs.rs/thiserror/1.0.24/thiserror/), a crate which provides a derive macro for `std::error::Error`, as this refactoring replaces several instances of `String` being used as an error type with structured error types implementing `Error`.

Let me know if there's anything that should be adjusted!

title: Add Send and Sync bounds to Rewrite so it can be shared between threads
Use analysis data in rewrite conditions
Improved e-matching for ground terms
Update main branch name for docs publishing.
Print eclass data in egraph dump

title: Use new const generic rust feature to implement trait
body: This generalizes the trait implementation for all n. This would raise the minimum Rust compiler version to 1.51. Not sure if it is worth it. I stumbled over the impl macro and thought, hey that would fit!

title: Use hashbrown for better performance
body:
Use the most recent version of https://crates.io/crates/hashbrown to get some performance improvements. It is slightly faster than the standard hashmap (which uses the same crate) as it has some recent improvements and some more inlining.

Seems all to be improved except for `lambda_fib`.

title: New rebuilding algorithm
body:
Rebuilding is much improved! The new algorithm's congruence closure part is closer to [Downey, Sethi, Tarjan](https://dl.acm.org/doi/pdf/10.1145/322217.322228), and the analysis data propagation is more precise with respect to merging.

Overall, the algorithm is simpler, easier to reason about, and more than twice as fast (in the rebuilding phase)!

Here are the overall speedups.
```
name                          cycles       diff
diff_power_harder           22340377 -15.87191%
diff_power_simple            5287483 -10.14223%
integ_one                    1349118 +0.342354%

integ_part2                 32280838 -30.36249%
```
